title: New Component Title
body:
Make sure you change the text colour to a complimentary and legible one if you use this background.
Select your text within the authoring tool and then change the colour, click more colours and then you can change the # to any of the Hex codes. Be aware this will also change it in the adapt authoring tool and it can sometime be hard to read. I'd recommend changing the colour once the text is final.

title: New Component Title
body:
There is a wealth of guidance available on this topic, including:

  • resource 1
  • resource 2
  • resource 3
  • resource 4

 

If you require more bespoke guidance, please contact the [insert team] at [insert hyperlinked email address].

title: Do you want a title?
body:
There might be times where you want a title on each block and then each component, or you might want a title on only one, or no title at all. 
The title that will be shown to learners is the "display" title in the box above the text box when editing.

To edit the title

If this box is greyed out you can either edit it in the main 'title' box directly above that, or you can click the unlink button to the right of the display title box and then enter the text you want.

To remove the title

Click the unlink button and then remove the text from the display title box. You will still need to enter a title in the main title box, but this wont be displayed as long as the two boxes are not 'linked'.

title: New Component Title
body:
You can also add in interactives such as carousels, hot graphics and accordians.

Please refer to the blank component template for all components set up.

_items.title: Example carousel
_items.body:
When using this option ensure your images are all a consistent size.
You also need to make sure the ARIA or Narrative title level is set to 3, this tells screen readers it is a sub heading within a section.
You should also include a good brief description of the image within the alternative text box below.

_graphic.alt: person completing paperwork

_items.title: Example carousel part two
_items.body: Here you might talk about the second stage of your narrative

_graphic.alt: image showing bar chart steadily increasing, bar 4 of 5 is highlighted red

title: New Component Title
body:
ARIA settings are how assistive technology knows which text is the main heading, sub-heading and so on and what order to read these in. Similar to HTML H1, H2 setting if you have ever used these. 

Any top or page heading should be set as ARIA 1, an Article or subheading should be ARIA 2 then any further headings should be ARIA 3.

_graphic.alt: Crowd of people made from wood

title: New Component Title
body:
When using an image make sure it is of a high quality resolution.

You also need to make sure you complete the alternative text option whenever you are using an image. The description should be clear but accurate. e.g. for this image  'crowd of wooden figures, some of which are painted black, blue, orange and red'.

title: New Component Title
body:
Welcome to Adapt!

This software is new for all us, so we are trying to build up a template that we can all use to ensure consistency across our courses. This is still in the early stages, so please feel free to add any hints and tips to this template course as you go along.

When you first load up the authoring tool, you'll see the dashboard; a view of every course created in the app. Also notice the button to create a new course in the dashboard's sidebar.

The adapt layout or path is:

Course>Page>Article (a main section)>block (subsection within the main section)>component (interactive, text or image)

title: New Component Title
body:
All courses should include the following:

  • introduction and aims of course on homepage
  • duration of each module
  • further information and support module
  • relevant GSS/AF theme

title: New Component Title
body:
The shared courses section will give you a list of courses others have created and shared within the system. In addition to being able to view these courses, you can also edit them (depending on your user account privileges).

To make a course you've authored yourself viewable in this section, you must enable the relevant configuration setting. This means that one person in the group who is making a course needs to create a new course, and then make it available to their team members. You can do this by going to Project settings -> Share with specific users and then add the relevant team members. Alternatively, you can tick the 'Share with all users box' but this will mean others can go in a potentially edit your course!

 

Please can you add in the good practice team account to your courses so that we can help you with any issues you find as you go along.

 

Once the course has been created, it should show up on the dashboard. Double click the course to  take you into the course editor.

title: New Component Title
body:
You can select a theme for each of your Adapt courses. In order to ensure consistency across the BPI products, you will have a choice of a GSS theme (as used in this course) or an Analysis Function theme. The theme depends on your intended audience.

These themes haven't been finalised yet, so don't worry about the theme just yet! You can easily import these at the end of your work.

title: Linking to another section/top of page/main menu
displayTitle: Linking to another section/top of page/main menu
body:
You can take the user to a different section of your course, e.g you might want 'Next module' or previous module as an option at the end of your page or module. 

Firstly you will need to get your destination ID

  1. Go to edit on the block or article you would like to link to
  2. Within the section you would like to link to e.g 'Block' select the Cog icon then 'copy ID' 
  3. this should give you a string of numbers and letters which is a unique ID for that section or page.

Next go to the place you would like to create the link from. you could create a new text box at the bottom of the page for example:

  1. Within the body of the linking item paste your code.
  2. Click source on the top left of the toolbar.
  3. Enter <a href="#Uniquename">TEXT HERE</a> then copy and paste the Unique ID after the # and making sure there is no space. You can then enter the text you would like within the TEXT HERE bit of this code.

 

Example takes you to Do you want a title

_items.prefix: The Welsh flag has a red
_items.suffix: on a green and white background

_feedback.correct: Correct, the Welsh flag is comprised of a red dragon on a green and white background.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect, the Welsh flag is comprised of a red dragon on a green and white background.

_partlyCorrect.final: Incorrect, the Welsh flag is comprised of a red dragon on a green and white background.

title: Avoiding commons mistakes
body:
There are a few errors people routinely make when creating accessible text or work:

  1. No bold for emphasis, this gives sighted users an unfair advantage over those using screen readers, a screen reader will not know to emphasise a bold word. Try to find another way to get your point across. Front loading a sentence is more effective.
  2. No italics, italics are harder to read. Note the instruction text automatically appears as italics within adapt, this is ok and meets the WCAG AA standard.
  3. Numbers one to ten should be written as words and anything higher should be written as numerals. 
  4. don't use - (hyphens) to show a range, use the word to e.g 2009 to 2019
  5. Don't use / (backslash) to show an either or option use the words e.g Users/readers should be users or readers.

title: Spellcheck
body:
Adapt does highlight misspelled words, however it will not correct them for you and it will not highlight any other mistakes such as double spaces, double words or grammatical mistakes. 

e.g. Adapt would have no issue with 'it sin the drawer' when what you meant to say was 'it's in the drawer'.

 

This is why we recommend creating your text in another programme such as Word and then copying it over once you are happy with the content.

title: Buttons
body:
The buttons in adapt have preset titles, e.g. on a quiz they will automatically be called submit or reset and so on. 

Unfortunately if the button text is more than two words, each word is capitalised. Which is a pain for accessibility and generally not good practice. you can enter your own text for these within the edit function of that component. 

It's best practice to only use capital letters at the start of the sentence (button phrase) and for any proper nouns.

 

The image shows how you can go in and edit the button titles, note these will initially be blank. I've just copied the text over and then gone through and ensured capitals are used appropriately. The Aria labels should be the same as the button text. Note the Aria label on the Hide correct answer section is what it will look like, the Aria label on the Show correct answer section is what it should look like.

title: Enlarging font
body:
There might be some instances where you need the font to be bigger in a specific section:

<font size="+2"">Text here</font>

title: Background code if needed
body:
If for some reason the background code has been deleted, or you need to change them for say the Analytical function colours then you will need to go to:

Dashboard>Project settings and scroll down to Custom CSS/LESS code at the end of the general section. 

In here you need to enter a line of code for each background colour you would like. 

The code is:

.cBlock-01 { background-colour: #AAAAAA; } 

you can change the number of the block for each different colour and also change the letters after the # to whatever the colour Hex code is. Make sure you note down which colour relates to which number as it will be easier when you apply the colours later on.

title: Question 2
body: Which of these is NOT a feature of quality statistics according to the Code of Practice?
instruction: Select one:

_items.text: They are based on appropriate data and methods
They are provided to users with no explanation of changes in methods

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done. 

The Code of Practice states that quality statistics are:

  • fit for purpose
  • based on appropriate data and methods
  • not materially misleading

It is important to communicate any quality concerns or changes in methodology to users.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

The Code of Practice states that quality statistics are:

  • fit for purpose
  • based on appropriate data and methods
  • not materially misleading

It is important to communicate any quality concerns or changes in methodology to users.

title: Question 3
body: Which of the following are possible consequences of poor-quality statistics?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: Reputational damage to the statistical producer
Loss of trust in the statistical producer

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

Poor quality statistics can lead to: 

  • Reputational damage to the statistical producer 
  • Mis-informed policy decisions 
  • Loss of trust in the statistical producer

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

Poor quality statistics can lead to: 

  • Reputational damage to the statistical producer 
  • Mis-informed policy decisions 
  • Loss of trust in the statistical producer

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost.

Poor quality statistics can lead to: 

  • Reputational damage to the statistical producer 
  • Mis-informed policy decisions 
  • Loss of trust in the statistical producer

title: Title here
body: The Quality pillar is underpinned by three principles.
instruction: Select each title to find out more:

_items.title: Q1: Suitable Data Sources
_items.body: Statistics should be based on the most appropriate data to meet intended uses. The impact of any data limitations for use should be assessed, minimised and explained.

_items.title: Q2: Sound Methods
_items.body: Producers of statistics and data should use the best available methods and recognised standards, and be open about their decisions.

_items.title: Q3: Assured Quality
_items.body: Producers of statistics and data should explain clearly how they assure themselves that statistics and data are accurate, reliable, coherent and timely.

title: Consequences
body: Poor quality statistics can have many negative impacts.
instruction: Click through each section to see some examples:

_items.title: Reputational damage
_items.body: We have a reputation to uphold as producers of statistics. Poor quality statistics harm our reputation with stakeholders, the public, and potentially even the international community.

_graphic.alt: blue plate fallen on the ground broken into many pieces

_items.title: Loss of trust
_items.body: Users will lose trust in our data if we make mistakes or publish poor quality information.

_graphic.alt: Man uses pen to fill out paperwork

_items.title: Financial loss
_items.body: There are financial impacts associated with poor quality, such as the cost of redoing work.

_graphic.alt: £5 and £20 bill notes

_items.title: Respondent burden
_items.body: If a survey isn't fit for purpose, we waste respondents' time.

_graphic.alt: hippo resting on a river bank

_items.title: Not meeting user needs
_items.body: If we don't listen to our users, we may focus our resources on the wrong area.

_graphic.alt: Dog wearing a carnival mask

_items.title: Misleading users
_items.body: If we don't publish adequate quality information, and fully explain any limitations of our work, users may misinterpret statistics and draw incorrect conclusions.

_graphic.alt: Road sign reading "wrong way"

title: Question one
body: Which of the following is NOT a dimension of quality according to ESS?
instruction: Select one:

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

The 5 Dimensions of Quality are:

  1. Relevance
  2. Comparability and Coherence
  3. Accessibility and Clarity
  4. Timeliness and Punctuality
  5. Accuracy and Reliability

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

The answer is Confidentiality.

The 5 Dimensions of Quality are:

  1. Relevance
  2. Comparability and Coherence
  3. Accessibility and Clarity
  4. Timeliness and Punctuality
  5. Accuracy and Reliability

title: Question two
body: Which of the following describes “timeliness”?
instruction: Select one:

_items.text: The degree to which data can be compared over time, region or other domain
Lapse of time between the period to which the data refer and publication of the estimate.
The degree to which statistics meet current and potential needs of users.
The lag between the planned date of publication and when something actually gets published.

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

Timeliness is "The lapse of time between the period to which the data refer and publication of the estimate".

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

Timeliness is "The lapse of time between the period to which the data refer and publication of the estimate".

title: Question three
body: Your team is working on a publication. The publication deadline is approaching but your data supplier has identified an issue with the confidence intervals in the data they have provided. You decide to delay publication until the issue has been resolved. This is an example of a trade-off between:
instruction: Select one:

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

This example is a trade-off between punctuality and accuracy.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

This example is a trade-off between punctuality and accuracy.

title: Question one
body: What are the three key areas you should quality assure?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

The three areas to quality assure are data, methods and processes, and outputs.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

The three areas to quality assure are data, methods and processes, and outputs.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost.

The three areas to quality assure are data, methods and processes, and outputs.

title: Quality assuring methods and processes (2nd part)
instruction: In choosing the right methods, you must consider the following:

_items.title: Nature of the data source and the steps in the data journey
_items.body:
You will need to choose the methods most likely to meet user needs, for example producing statistics at an appropriate level of detail.

Are there known issues where the statistics fall short of meeting those needs?

_graphic.alt: Sign post pointing in different directions against a sunset

_items.title: Methods that were once fit for purpose might not always be
_items.body:
Changes in the data source, the data journey or methodological developments can all mean that a new approach is required.

You may need to seek advice from outside, perhaps through consultancy, or a process of peer review.

_graphic.alt: 3D pie chart split into three section, red largest, blue middle then yellow smallest

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body: Aim for transparency in the choice of the methods (which should be open to detailed scrutiny and described frankly) and in the reporting of the implementation.

_graphic.alt: Line drawing of a squirrel standing up

_items.title: Full or partial dual running
_items.body:
You might recalculate some or all of the statistics using an alternative software package, or the same package but blinded from the original process.

For example, make sure that the system has picked up the correct data files and verify checks have been completed.

_graphic.alt: Line drawing of a squirrel standing up

title: What is Quality Assurance?
body: Quality assurance (QA) is about identifying, anticipating and avoiding the problems that can arise from our data inputs or the methods and processes we use to calculate statistics.
instruction: Click through each section to find out more about the core components of QA:

_items.title: Dimensions of quality
_items.body: QA should include assessment of statistics against the five dimensions of quality.

_graphic.alt: Rubrik's cube with the sides not aligned

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
You must ensure that sufficient time and resources are available for quality assurance.

This should be proportionate to the likelihood of quality concerns and to the importance of the statistics.

_graphic.alt: Hourglass on the ground

_items.title: Curiosity
_items.body: As a statistical producer, it is your role to be curious. Don’t take data at face value. Items that look unusual or inaccurate should be investigated and verified.

_graphic.alt: Window screen with paper notifications and stencil sticker reading "#becurious"

_items.title: QA logs
_items.body:
QA checklists are a good way of documenting QA. 

For further information and guidance please see here.

_graphic.alt: Hand holding a pen and ticking through boxes in a checklist

title: Check your knowledge!
body: Which of the following are true for a Reproducible Analytical Pipeline?
instruction: Select all that apply:

_items.text: We can automate the statistical workflow and provide a full audit trail.
Processes are time consuming and frustrating because steps are hard to replicate.
Anybody can follow the steps we took and understand how we got to our published results.
Introduces risk and increase the burden of QA.

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

With RAP we can automate the statistical workflow and provide a full audit trail. Therefore anybody can follow the steps we took and understand how we got to our published result

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

With RAP we can automate the statistical workflow and provide a full audit trail. Therefore anybody can follow the steps we took and understand how we got to our published results.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost.

With RAP we can automate the statistical workflow and provide a full audit trail. Therefore anybody can follow the steps we took and understand how we got to our published results.

_items.title: Taking a pragmatic approach
_items.body:
It is not necessary to automate a statistical workflow end-to-end to use reproducible analysis ideas to improve timelines, auditability and quality of statistics.

You can improve efficiency by starting small and identifying quick wins to reduce the level of manual intervention needed.

_graphic.alt: Sign post pointing in different directions against a sunset

_items.title: Reproducible analysis is not a cure-all
_items.body:
It supports effective quality assurance but does not remove the need for proper analytical oversight of the end-to-end process.

Automation is not about implementing and forgetting or building black boxes that cannot be maintained properly.

_graphic.alt: 3D pie chart split into three section, red largest, blue middle then yellow smallest

_items.title: Regular reviewing the RAP workflow
_items.body:
Make sure your RAP workflow remains fit for purpose.

A curious analyst will be able to identify issues that automatic tests many not pick up.

_graphic.alt: Line drawing of a squirrel standing up

_items.title: Use your expertise
_items.body: While RAP can automatically generate standard text, graphs and tables, statistical reports will require an analyst’s expertise to write clear, useful commentary.

_graphic.alt: Line drawing of a squirrel standing up

title: Benefits of RAP
body:
RAP improves quality due to the reduced risk of errors occurring in the production process. Automation can also improve timeliness, freeing up analyst time to focus on the interpretation of the statistics.

The production process is coded, in a way that is completely transparent, auditable and verifiable. QA is embedded into the code, using logging and automatic testing.
instruction: Click through each section to find out more:

_items.title: Automation
_items.body: By making our analysis reproducible, mainly though automation, we make it easier for others to quality assure, access, critique and re-use our methods and results, and for colleagues to assure what we have done.

_graphic.alt: Laptop screen showing code

_items.title: Version control methods
_items.body:
We bring together the code and the data that generate the outputs with version control methods from software engineering.

This means we can automate the statistical workflow and provide a full audit trail.

_graphic.alt: Workflow on the board

_items.title: Decisions
_items.body: RAP lets us be fully open about the decisions we have made, so that others can follow what we did and re-create the steps.

_graphic.alt: Man standing in front of fridges with many products in them

_items.title: Code of Practice for Statistics
_items.body: Reproducible analysis supports the requirements of Code of Practice for Statistics around quality assurance and transparency.

_graphic.alt: Code of Practice

title: Case study:  Department for Transport
body:
The Department for Transport (DfT) has been working hard to implement RAP into their processes. They have set a target of 2020 to have RAP implemented, at least partially, in all of their statistical output production processes.

DfT is growing the capability of their statisticians through training courses, the RAP champion network and a Coffee and Coding club. If they identify a piece of work or project that would benefit from automation, the team is supported to get the relevant training. The Coffee and Coding club is an informal setting in which colleagues discuss coding and any challenges they have. These sessions were originally run monthly but were so popular they now run weekly.

The data for Search and Rescue Helicopter statistics are produced by aggregating monthly spreadsheets from the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. These were checked manually, but the checks have now been automated using R, with a report produced by R Markdown including maps, counts and tabulations and an R Flex interactive dashboard. This makes it quicker and easier for the person carrying out QA to spot discrepancies.

Further information can be found in the Code of Practice for Statistics: V4 case study.

title: Further support
body:
A  RAP learning pathway is available on the Learning Hub. The Government Digital Service has created a free online training course, supported by the RAP companion – a comprehensive guide to implementing RAP.

There is the RAP champions network run by the GSS Best Practice and Impact Division. This includes a Slack channel for RAP champions. You can find out your local champion on the GSS website.

With increased use of software tools, such as R or Python in producing statistics, there is more need for producers of statistics to be able to quality assure the coding that has been used to produce statistics. Guidance on this can be found in the Duck Book.

The Office for Statistical Regulation (OSR) has published its findings and recommendations on how to overcome barriers in adopting RAP. A case study of transforming processes and implementing RAP from the Centre for Crime and Justice (CCJ) is also available here.

_graphic.alt: Various pipelines joining taken from below.

title: Q1. Quality assuring data
body:
Editing and validation is most effective when carried out as close to the data source as possible. In practice, editing and validation continue after contact with the reporting unit concludes.

What you can check on the data:

  • missing values represent an error, or a legitimate refusal or don’t know
  • check for any logical or arithmetic relationships in the data
  • check if values fall inside an acceptable or the expected change

title: Quality assuring methods and processes
body:
Methods and processes transform data and perform calculations as we move along the data journey from raw inputs to final statistics.

To ensure quality you need to be confident that the methods and processes chosen are appropriate and that they have been implemented correctly.

title: Quality assuring outputs
body:
By drawing on quality management information accumulated in the production chain you can assess statistical outputs against the five quality dimensions, taking into account user needs.

As with raw data, you should explain unusual changes or patterns where one area departs from others.

Preparing outputs for dissemination can introduce risks, especially if manual processing is needed.

title: GSBPM
body: The Generic Statistical Business Process Model (GSBPM) is a process for producing statistical outputs. When we talk about quality statistics in government, we are referring to quality in all stages of the cycle. Your work is part of a bigger picture and it’s important to think about and coordinate with other areas. Users are at the heart of quality statistics, at every stage in the cycle you should consider their needs.
instruction: Click through each stage of the cycle to see an example:

_items.body: Specify needs: identify the need for the statistics, establish high level objectives for statistical outputs, check data availability
Design: decide most appropriate collection instruments and methods, design your outputs and services to be produced, determine sampling criteria and methodology
Build: build collection and analysis components, carry out cognitive testing of questionnaires
Collect: set up and run collection, monitor data collection, check structure and integrity of information collected
Process: review and validate data, quality assure work of data supplier, calculate weights and aggregates
Analyse: using appropriate methods to prepare draft outputs, interpret and explain them, and finalise the output for release
Disseminate: produce dissemination products such as press releases, interactive graphics, and linked open data, and provide users with quality information alongside the output
Evaluate: seek feedback from your users, make recommendations for change

title: A COVID-19 Case Study
body: One real-life example of the serious impacts of poor quality can be seen in the case study below.
instruction: Click through each section to see the whole story:

_items.title: What happened:
_items.body: In Sept/Oct 2020, a “technical error” caused almost 16,000 cases of COVID-19 to go unreported. There were 8 days of incomplete data, an average of 1,980 missed cases each day.

_graphic.alt: Drawn picture of a coronavirus

_items.title: How it happened:
_items.body: The problem came in the way data from testing agencies were collated by PHE. Agencies sent data in the form of .csv files and PHE combined them in Excel – but using an old version with limited row numbers. Leftover data were disregarded.

_graphic.alt: Headline from a news site reading "The U.K. lost 16,000 Covid cases because it doesn't understand Microsoft excel"

_items.title: What it led to:
_items.body: This led to reputational damage on an international scale, and a lack of trust from the UK public in the Test and Trace program and in government. It is not known what impact this may have had on the spread of coronavirus.

_graphic.alt: Headline from BBC News reading "Covid: Test error 'should never have happened' - Hancock"

title: Introduction to template
body:
If you wish to develop your knowledge further, the following courses may be of interest:

  • Introducing the Code of Practice for Statistics
  • Introduction to Data Quality

title: The 5 Dimensions
instruction: Click on each dimension for more information and examples:

_items.title: Relevance
_items.body:
Statistics must meet the needs of users.

Statistics producers should consider whether to produce new statistics to meet identified information gaps. An example of this can be seen in the ONS Crime Survey for England and Wales. A set of self-completion questions on adult recollection of abuse has been developed through consultation with stakeholders. These were implemented in the 2018 data collection and will help provide valuable information on what is a sensitive topic (see Improving Crime Statistics for England and Wales for further information).

_items.title: Accuracy and Reliability
_items.body:
Statistics should accurately and reliably portray reality.

Information on accuracy should be monitored and reported regularly to users. We may be able to estimate some aspects of accuracy from the data. For example, in the road safety statistics publication from the Department for Transport, they quantify the uncertainty around the estimated number of drink drive road deaths.

In the Department for Transport road safety statistics publication, two estimates of drink drive road deaths are published. The first is published in February, just over a year after the end of the reference year with the final estimate published in August of the same year e.g. the first estimate of the number of drink drive road deaths in 2017 was published in February 2019 with the final estimate published in August 2019. The initial estimate of drink drive road deaths is less accurate than the final one because the data available at the time of initial publication is incomplete. Reliability is measured from these scheduled revisions by the closeness of the early estimates to the revised ones.

_items.title: Timeliness and Punctuality
_items.body:
Statistics are released in a timely and punctual manner.

An example of timeliness is the Faster indicators of UK economic activity project being undertaken by the ONS. The aim is to provide faster insight into the state of the UK economy to policymakers and analysts in order to make informed, timely decisions on matters, such as the setting of interest rates, which affect the whole UK.

With regards to punctuality, the release of both regular and ad-hoc official statistics should be pre-announced through a 12 month release calendar with a specific release date given at least four weeks in advance where practicable. NHS England have a 12 month release calendar to enable users to see what we will be publishing over the year.

_items.title: Comparability and Coherence
_items.body:
Statistics are consistent internally and over time, and are comparable between different geographical regions.

For example, the Department for  Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Taking Part Survey began in 2005 and its core questions have remained similar since the survey was first launched so that a consistent time series is available for many topics.

An example on coherence can be seen in the ONS baby name statistics for England and Wales. Baby names are derived by using the exact spelling of the first name given on the birth certificate. This method is consistent internationally with countries such as Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Netherlands and the United States. This means that ONS figures can be compared with the numbers from these other countries (see Baby names Quality and Methodology Information (QMI) for more information).

_items.title: Accessibility and Clarity
_items.body:
Statistics need to be presented in a clear and understandable form.

From 2020, public sector websites will have a legal obligation to meet accessibility standards. Accessible communication formats should be used which work with the most commonly used assistive technologies. Data should also be made available at the highest level of detail that is practicable.

We have a duty to support everybody who needs to use government statistics by providing the information they need in a way that is clear and accessible. Our statistical releases should use plain language. Technical terms, acronyms and definitions should be defined and explained when this is appropriate, to ensure that the statistics can be used effectively.

title: Trade-offs txt
body:
It is impossible to hit every dimension perfectly when producing statistics, and prioritising one dimension will almost always require you to sacrifice another. These are trade-offs and it will be up to you to decide which dimensions are priorities in your work, and how to mitigate any trade-offs you make.

 

As always, decisions around trade-offs should be based around user needs.

_graphic.alt: Star chart with the five dimensions in each side

title: Quality Considerations Accordion
instruction: Click to see some examples:

_items.title: Assessment of user needs and perceptions
_items.body:
It’s important to gauge what your user actually needs from your statistics, and what their expectations are. 

For more information on understanding the needs of the users, see the GSS user engagement strategy.

_items.title: Cost, performance and respondent burden
_items.body: Lengthy or complicated data collection exercises can be burdensome for respondents taking part, which can affect accuracy e.g. by increasing drop out rates.

_items.title: Confidentiality, transparency and security
_items.body: This links to the Trustworthiness pillar in the Code of Practice, mentioned in the previous module. The Trustworthiness and Value pillars tie in closely with quality, so it is important to bear these concepts in mind too when thinking about quality.

_graphic.alt: Human figure assembling Legos that do not fit very well.

title: Holly test
body: Ed Humpherson, the Director General for Regulation at the Office for Statistics Regulation, gives an overview of the quality pillar of the Code of Practice in the following video.
instruction: Press play to watch:

title: Manual Statistical Processes
body:
Manual statistical production processes:

  • introduce risk and increase the burden of QA
  • are time consuming and frustrating because steps are hard to replicate quickly
  • are prone to error
  • input data and outputs are not connected directly, only through the analyst’s manual intervention.

title: Flipcards
instruction: Flip the cards below for more considerations regarding QA in your data's journey:

frontImage.alt: Hand holding a pen and going through a checklist

_items.backBody: You will need to know about the processes used along this data journey and how quality is checked at each step.

frontImage.alt: Individual's hands working on a laptop showing a dashboard with multiple charts and graphs

_items.backBody: Your own quality assurance, should be complementary, confirming what has already been established and filling in the gaps.

title: Quality Checks
body: Things to consider when quality assuring your data:

_items.title: Aim for a cost-effective set of edit and validation checks.
_items.body: Focus on changes that could have an impact on your analysis. Don’t focus too much on details that cannot substantially impact your analysis.

_items.title: Make sure you understand the use of the data.
_items.body: This will help to highlight any concerns on data quality.

_items.title: Use graphs to examine emerging patterns.
_items.body: For example, line graphs will show change and whether the change is typical of recent history and other subsets of the data. A scatter plot will reveal outliers.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Steps to consider for QA outputs:

_items.body:
Checking tables:

  • Check breakdowns sum to totals
  • Cross check totals between tables
  • Compare with previous years
  • Check formulas are linking to correct cells
  • Compare with other sources
  • Are there any revisions?

_graphic.alt: Example table concerning annual household income

_items.body:
Proof reading steps:

  • Cross check figures in publication against tables
  • Check explanations of key trends
  • Check footnote numbering
  • Do hyperlinks work?
  • Are chart and tables numbers in the right order?

_graphic.alt: Hand holding a pen going through a checklist

_items.body:
Publication steps:

  • Get sign off from your Head of Profession
  • Check who has pre-release access
  • Make contact with press office
  • Check publication on website once published

_graphic.alt: Press printing newspapers

_items.body:
Post publication steps:

  • Review what went well and what didn’t go so well
  • What improvements can  you make for next time?
  • Engage with users of the publication to get feedback

_graphic.alt: Man sitting on  bench reading a newspaper

title: New Component Title
body: For effective QA you must be clear on roles and responsibilities. It is not enough to say that an individual will carry out some QA.
instruction: Click through the sections below to find out more:

_items.body: Be clear on the nature and the extent of the QA. When this is clear for everyone involved, you can reassure yourself that there are known gaps and that any duplication of effort is appropriately targeted.

_graphic.alt: Underwater picture of crystal clear water

_items.body: Think what will work best in your team when allocating roles, given the time and resource available.

_graphic.alt: Man and woman are exchanging a high-five in front of a laptop

_items.body: Senior grades do not necessarily ensure better results. Senior colleagues can take a strategic look at the consequences of your findings and place them in a wider context. They might sign-off a statistical bulletin but would be unlikely to do detailed checks.

_graphic.alt: An individual is playing chess

title: New Component Title
body: The ESS Code of Practice lays out 15 principles.
instruction: Click through the sections to find out more:

_items.body:
Principles 1-6: The Institutional Environment

Institutional and organisational factors have a significant influence on the effectiveness and credibility of a statistical authority developing, producing and disseminating European Statistics. The relevant principles are professional independence, mandate for data collection, adequacy of resources, quality commitment, statistical confidentiality, impartiality and objectivity.

_graphic.alt: British politicians in the House of Commons

_items.body:
Principles 7-10: Statistical Processes

European and other international standards, guidelines and good practices are fully observed in the statistical processes used by the statistical authorities to develop, produce and disseminate European Statistics, while constantly striving for innovation. The relevant principles are sound methodology, appropriate statistical procedures, non-excessive burden on respondents and cost effectiveness.

_graphic.alt: Caclulator

_items.body:
Principles 11-15: Statistical Output

Output quality is measured by the extent to which the statistics are relevant, accurate and reliable, timely, coherent, comparable across regions and countries, and readily accessible by users, i.e. the principles of statistical output.

_graphic.alt: Laptop showing a dashboard with many charts and graphs

title: New Component Title
body:
• The European Statistics Code of Practice is the cornerstone of the common quality framework of the European Statistical System (ESS).

• The ESS Code of Practice and the UK Code of Practice for Statistics are complementary in assessing and assuring statistical quality. By following the principles and practices in the UK Code of Practice for Statistics and addressing any concerns that arise, you can collect evidence on statistical process and output quality.

• More information on ESS and the ESS Code of Practice websites.

title: Census trade-off example
instruction: Click on the arrow to see differences in the quality dimensions between the 2011 and 2021 censuses:

_items.body:
The example star diagram shows that while most measures were being met fairly well in the 2011 Census, there was room for improvement on the timeliness and punctuality dimension.  

 

For the 2021 Census, considerations were made on balancing accuracy and timeliness:

_graphic.alt: Star chart with the 5 dimensions in each side. The 'Timeliness and Punctuality' dimension is very short.

_items.body:
ONS have planned for users to access Census data using a flexible dissemination tool: this will allow them to create their own outputs before Census offices can release topic analyses, which would provide users with additional insight and support appropriate interpretation of the data and statistics. 

OSR commended this decision, where user needs were accounted for and changes were made to try to address the trade-off between timeliness and accuracy.

_graphic.alt: Star chart with the 5 dimensions in each side. The 'Timeliness and Punctuality' dimension is here longer but 'Accuracy and Reliability' is shorter than before..

title: New Component Title
body:
Statistics are used to help make important decisions. To properly inform those decisions, users need to know about the quality of the statistics and how this feeds through into effective use.

Whether you are designing a survey, collecting data, or analysing statistics, quality needs to be at the forefront of everything you do.

title: txt
body:
How do we end up with poor quality statistics? If quality is not at the forefront when producing statistics, the following can cause problems:

  • Inappropriate/suboptimal methods 
  • Formula errors
  • Insufficient data validation (internal or external)
  • No explanation of changes to users

title: txt
body: For further information on the error please visit this blog. Quality Assurance could have prevented this – we’ll talk more about this in Module 3.

title: New Component Title
body: The GSS Quality Strategy was launched in June 2019 and has 4 goals:

_items.title: Goal 1
_items.body: We will all understand the importance of our role in producing high quality statistics

_graphic.alt: Five individuals discussing in a room

_items.title: Goal 2
_items.body: We will ensure our data are of sufficient quality and communicate the quality implications to users

_graphic.alt: A hand holding a pen and going through a checklist

_items.title: Goal 3
_items.body: We will anticipate emerging trends and changes and prepare for them using innovative methods.

_graphic.alt: A graph of a timeseries with various forecasted scenarios depicted for the future

_items.title: Goal 4
_items.body:
We will implement automated processes to make our analysis reproducible.

We will talk more about Reproducible Analytical Pipelines (RAP) in Module 4.

_graphic.alt: Pipeline going through the forest

title: Question 1
body: What are the 3 principles under the quality pillar in the Code of Practice for Statistics?
instruction: Select one:

_items.text: Q1 Clarity and insight; Q2 Orderly release; Q3 Assured quality
Q1 Transparent process management; Q2 Accessibility; Q3 Suitable data sources
Q1 Suitable data sources; Q2 Sound methods; Q3 Assured quality
Q1 Relevance to users; Q2 Quality assurance; Q3 Sound methods

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

The three principles under the quality pillar in the Code of Practice for Statistics are Q1 Suitable data sources; Q2 Sound methods; Q3 Assured quality.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

The correct answer is Q1 Suitable data sources; Q2 Sound methods; Q3 Assured quality.

title: New Component Title
body:
According to the Code of Practice, quality statistics “fit their intended uses, are based on appropriate data and methods, and are not materially misleading”.

Quality is a pillar of the Code of Practice along with Trustworthiness and Value. Without quality, both trust and value are undermined.

title: New Component Title
body: To find out more about the Code of Practice for our statistics, please look at our Code of Practice e-learning course.
instruction: Flip the following card:

frontImage.alt: Front cover of the Code of Practice for Statistics booklet

_items.backBody: The course includes a module on the quality pillar, as well as on trustworthiness and value.

title: Question two
body: Which of the following definitions best describes quality assurance?
instruction: Select one:

_items.text: Identifying, anticipating and avoiding problems in our statistics
Responding to observed problems in our statistics

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done. 

Quality Assurance is about "Identifying, anticipating and avoiding problems in our statistics".

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. 

Quality Assurance is about "Identifying, anticipating and avoiding problems in our statistics".

title: Question three
body: Which of the following is NOT an important characteristic of a robust quality assurance process?
instruction: Select one:

_items.text: A good understanding of the data journey

_feedback.title: How did I do?
_feedback.correct:
Correct, well done.

Having lots of time and resource can be useful but it is not an essential part of robust quality assurance.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. 

Having lots of time and resource can be useful but it is not an essential part of robust quality assurance.

title: New Component Title
body: Principles 11-15 are used as the five dimensions to measure quality. They provide a useful framework for informing users about the quality of statistical outputs. Producers should use the framework as the basis for reporting information on the quality of their statistics.

title: New Component Title
body:
For effective quality assurance, we need to know how data got from the initial input to a statistical publication. We refer to this as the data journey.

You should know the exact circumstances in which data were input. Ask yourself:

  • What was the question asked?
  • What was on the collection form?
  • If the input process was automated, did automatic checks prevent invalid entries?
  • What were those checks?
  • Is a particular field crucial to their work or is collecting it a necessary chore to be completed with minimum effort?

title: New Component Title
body:
Reproducible analysis is about getting the same results when we repeat a piece of analysis using the same data/methods. One of the most important things for RAP is opening up the production process so that anybody can follow the steps we took and understand how we got to our published results.

A reproducible workflow is called Reproducible Analytical Pipeline or RAP.

_graphic.alt: magnifying glass
Ancient ruins of three tall pillars under the blue sky
ice cream cone fallen down with ice cream outside of the cone

Rubrik's cube with sides not aligned
Man explaining a schematic on a whiteboard to another individual
Four individuals discussing in high-v jackets in a construction site
Calculator
Electronic device with many output cables

Triangle road signs with exclamation point signifying danger

title: Example - text
body:
The Best Practice and Impact Division (BPI) helped the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG) to improve their QA processes via their free consultation service. By implementing the recommendations of the BPI report, MHCLG achieved clearer and more comprehensive outputs on rough sleeping. 

For further information on how the BPI helped the MHCLG please see this blog.

title: Resources
body:
• Code of Practice for Statistics
  • Quality Statistics in Government
  • GSS Quality Strategy
  • ONS Statistical Quality Improvement Strategy

_graphic.alt: Best Practice and Impact division logo
